QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 October 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What involvement has (a) his Department, (b) AUSSAT Pty Ltd, (c) Telecom Australia and (d) the Overseas Telecommunications Commission had with each other and other organisations including educational institutions and Departments on the possible use of Domsat, the domestic satellite for educational purposes in remote areas of Australia.
(2) What aspects of the education satellite issue are being addressed by each of these organisations.
(3) Have interdepartmental committees or other committees been established to examine the introduction and use of Domsat; if so, (a) what are the committees and (b) who are the members.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows, based on advice received from statutory authorities within the Communications portfolio and the Department of Communications:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2)-(a) The provision of educational services is the responsibility of the education authorities, but I am concerned to ensure that opportunities to provide educational services via the Australian satellite are known and understood by the educational authorities.
To this end, the Department of Communications has already established direct liaison with educational institutions, community groups, Federal and State Education Departments.

Additionally, my Department has been represented by observers at meetings of the Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee on the Educational Use of Communications Technology, and made active inputs to a report entitled ' Potential Use of the Australian Satellite Communications Systems for School of the Air and Enhanced Educational Services' in March 1983.

Since then, my Department has co-operated closely with the Queensland Department of Education in a study of specific applications of this report to the Mt Isa School of the Air, a project which was endorsed by the Committee.

The above reports have involved close liaison with and contributions from AUSSAT Pty Ltd and Telecom Australia, and I understand that these reports are being drawn to the attention of education authorities throughout Australia by those responsible.

My Department and the authorities in my portfolio are continuing to provide advice and resources as appropriate to assist educational authorities in their own consideration of satellite-based educational services.

(b) AUSSAT Pty Limited has had considerable involvement with the Department of Communications, Telecom Australia, Commonwealth and State Departments of Education, Institutions of Technical and Further Education together with organisations and Community groups such as the Isolated Children's Parents' Association and the Royal Flying Doctor Service representing people in remote and isolated areas of Australia.

Involvement of AUSSAT with the above groups takes the form of presentations and discussions to public meetings and conferences, formal and informal discussion, provision of specialised technical information, publication of information papers and participation in satellite demonstrations. The satellite demonstration will occur in 1986, centered on the Mount Isa School of the Air, and has been designed to demonstrate the capabilities of the satellite system for distance education.

The purpose of this wide ranging consultation is to ensure that satellite users and responsible educational authorities and associated community groups are aware of the technical capabilities of the satellite system.

(c) Telecom has provided extensive assistance to educational authorities and organisations to enable them to trial facilities and services over the terrestrial network which simulate corresponding satellite facilities and services. This provides those bodies with the experience required to assess the potential of the satellite to provide various educational services.

Telecom has also co-operated in the study prepared for the Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee on the Educational Use of Communications Technology called ' Potential Use of the Australian Satellite Communications Systems for School of the Air and Enhanced Educational Services'.

(d) The Overseas Telecommunications Commission was the interim owner and manager of the satellite from September 1980 until November 1981, when AUSSAT Pty Ltd was established. The Commission no longer has this responsibility.

(3) The principal committee concerned with the use of the Australian satellite for educational purposes is the Commonwealth-State Advisory Committee on the Educational Use of Communications Technology. The committee comes within the responsibility of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. The Department of Communications is represented by observers when invited.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Townhouse Development: Red Hill, Australian Capital Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 19 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When was the decision made to allow townhouse development on section 57, Red Hill, Australian Capital Territory.
(2) What consultation was carried out with the local community.
(3) Were normal administrative procedures adopted in relation to this proposed development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am informed by the National Capital Development Commission that-

(1) The residential land use policy for the site was determined by NCDC in November 1979 and the Minister for the Capital Territory informed in accordance with Section 12 of the National Capital Development Commission Act, 1957.

(2) The Commission has undertaken an extensive program of consultation since the site was first proposed for residential development in 1976. At that time the plans showing the proposed use were placed on exhibition, residents in the vicinity were invited by letter to comment on the proposals and a public meeting was held. At that meeting the Commission undertook to prepare plans showing possible alternative developments for discussion, however, with the slowdown in Canberra's growth the proposals did not proceed at that stage. In August 1979 the then Minister asked for resolution of the status of the sites for which residential development had been proposed in 1976. Public comment was again sought on 7 sites, including Section 57, Red Hill.

Draft development conditions for Section 57 were sent to nearby residents and contact was re-established with representatives of the group that met with the Commission in 1977. A second public meeting was held.

The land use for the site was subsequently determined by the Commission and endorsed by the then Minister in November 1979 as 'Residential-Medium Density Housing'. The land use decision was advertised by an advertisement in the Canberra Times on 24 November 1979.

In July 1983 the site was passed by the Commission to my Department for release . The Commission subsequently let a contract in August 1983 for site servicing. In delineating the site boundaries and determining access, the previous comments made by residents were noted.

When site servicing started, nearby residents wrote to the Commission and myself expressing concern about the development. The Commission had invited residents to discuss the proposed development conditions but this invitation was declined. A second invitation was issued by the Commission and residents have accepted the offer to discuss the proposed development conditions and other relevant aspects.
(3) Yes.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Norfolk Island: Electoral Enrolment of Temporary Entry Permit Holders

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories and Local Government, upon notice , on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island, on 24 March 1983, pass and submit for assent a Bill for an Act to amend the Legislative Assembly Ordinance of 1979.

(2) Did that Ordinance provide that temporary entry permit holders intending to reside permanently on Norfolk Island, if permitted to do so, and having been resident for a period of at least two years, would now be entitled to enroll and to vote for the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island.
(3) Was the proposed law one which required the assent of the Governor-General.

(4) Did the Governor-General on 14 April 1983, acting on advice of the Federal Executive Council, withhold assent on section 4 of the Legislative Assembly Amendment Act 1983, which section permits enrolment of some temporary entry permit holders, and yet assent to the remainder of the Bill dealing with other aspects of the Legislative Assembly Ordinance; if so, why did the Federal Executive Council advise the Governor-General to withhold his assent in this instance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 23 March 1983 the Legislative Assembly of Norfolk Island passed a Bill or an Act to amend the Legislative Assembly Ordinance 1979. The Bill was presented to the Deputy Administrator of the Island, who at the time was performing the duties of the Administrator, for assent on 24 March 1983.
(2) Yes.
(3) Yes.
(4) Yes. The Legislative Assembly was informed of the reason why assent was withheld in a message from the Administrator provided pursuant to section 24 of the Norfolk Island Act.

Assent was withheld because it was considered undesirable to change the qualification for enrolment on the electoral roll of Norfolk Island before giving expression to the wishes of the existing electorate for the holding of an immediate general election. This was in accordance with the wishes of the majority of the electorate as expressed in a referendum held in February 1983.

It might be noted that on 3 August 1983, a Bill with provisions identical to those of section 4 of the Legislative Assembly (Amendment) Act 1983 was considered by the Third Legislative Assembly. This Bill was rejected by a majority of Assembly members who constitute the elected representatives of the people of Norfolk Island.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 2 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When (a) was the Cape Byron lighthouse tower last painted and (b) will it be painted next.
(2) What is the expected cost of painting the tower.
(3) What (a) is the value of paint presently held at the lighthouse and (b) amount is suitable for painting the tower.
(4) For what period has this paint been at the lighthouse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The exterior of the tower was last fully painted in June 1976, with the interior being fully painted in November 1978. Partial painting of the structure has been carried out at infrequent intervals since those times.
(b) Both the tower exterior and interior are being fully painted November- December 1983.
(2) About $16,000, including cost of Departmental labour.
(b) The amount of paint required to completely paint the tower is some 240 litres costing approximately $1,200. The paint presently held at the lightstation is suitable for this task.
(4) Since September 1983.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether the last offensive by Vietnam was directed against the Nong Chan Camp in Cambodia; if so, (a) was the population of the camp reasonably estimated at 20,000 and (b) what happened to the population.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: During the last dry season offensive by the Vietnamese, the KPNLF military base and civilian camp at Nong Chan was attacked in February-March 1983. The population of the camp could reasonably be estimated at around 20,000. These people were moved to an evacuation site at Prey Chan. We understand that from July 1983 the inhabitants of Prey Chan were to be moved to a more permanent site at Sanro Changan.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 16 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to complaints by amateur radio operators that the 27 MHz channel has been lost to citizen's band radio.
(2) Did his Department indicate to amateur radio operators that the CB radio use of this channel would be only until mid-1982 after which it would revert to amateur radio use.
(3) Does he intend any revision of the channel in the near future to accommodate the requirements of amateur radio operators.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) It is correct that when the Citizens Band Radio Service (CBRS) was introduced in 1977, the then Government indicated that the use of the 27 MHz band was an interim measure which would be phased out by July 1982. Following an extensive review of the CBRS in which comment was invited from all interested parties and organisations, the Government, in October 1980, announced that the 27 MHz band was to be retained by the CBRS beyond 1982.

(3) There is no intention to vary the existing arrangements in the near future. I should mention, however, that since 1981, the amateur service has received additional frequency allocations in the 1.8, 3.5, 7 and 50 MHz bands. The amateur service has also been allocated additional spectrum in the 10, 18 and 24 MHz bands. I firmly believe that the allocation of these additional frequencies to the amateur service more than adequately compensates for the loss to that service of the 27 MHz band.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: What will be the function of the Naval Technical Services Section of his Department with respect to (a) design and (b) construction of the 2 FFG type vessels proposed for Williamstown Naval Dockyard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) Naval Technical Services have been closely involved in defining the design baseline for the two FFG type vessels to be built at Williamstown Naval Dockyard . The design baseline for these vessels is the configuration of HMAS Darwin, the last of four FFGs being built in the United States for the Royal Australian Navy , with the Australian Mulloka Sonar installed instead of the American AN-SQS-56 sonar. Naval Technical Services have an ongoing role in undertaking the following design functions:
(1) managing preparation of the Mulloka design change package;
(2) defining the requirements for the preparation and issue of working drawings to Williamstown;
(3) investigations into acceptability of substituting Australian sourced equipments and materials;
(4) review FFG class design changes for relevance to the two vessels to be built at Williamstown;
(5) maintenance of specifications;
(6) acting as design authority for major equipments to be built in Australia, for example, 76 mm gun and propeller system.

(b) Naval Technical Services will be responsible for generally undertaking their traditional functions associated with a local construction program. Responsibility for the production aspects will be vested in the Australian Frigate Project Director who reports to the Director General Naval Production.
